document.docAuthor: Phillips, Gary, Moulton, John K. & Bernard, Ernest C.
document.masterDocTitle: Heth pivari n. sp. (Nematoda: Ransomnematoidea: Hethidae) from the indigenous North American millipede Narceus gordanus (Spirobolida: Spirobolidae), with keys for worldwide Heth spp.

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Heth pivari n. sp. (Nematoda: Ransomnematoidea: Hethidae) from the indigenous North American millipede Narceus gordanus (Spirobolida: Spirobolidae), with keys for worldwide Heth spp.

paragraph.keyLead: 1. Multiple cuticular knobâ€“like papillae in anterior esophageal region............................................. 2
- Knob-like papillae absent near head region, rarely one or two close to the cervical collar............................ 9
2. Lateral cervical collar spines reaching or overlapping proximal base of anterior lateral spines........................ 3
- Lateral cervical collar spines not reaching anterior lateral spines................................................ 6
3. Anterior and posterior lateral spines about equal in length..................................................... 4

- Posterior lateral spines much longer than anterior spines ( Fig. 11G ); anterior anal lip normal, without large lobe; female 2,340 â€“ 3,230 Î¼m long...............................................................................
H. initiensis

4. Anterior anal lip with large lobe extending over anus; female 2,610 â€“4,225 Î¼m long ( Fig. 11E )............
H. impalutiensis

5. Shield length and width about equal ( Fig. 11M ); female 1,365 â€“2,075 Î¼m long..........................
H. taynguyeni

- Shield longer than wide ( Fig. 12C ); females 2,550 â€“2,640 Î¼m long.................................
H. vietnamensis

6. Shield width twice that of its length; female
2,190 â€“4,483 Âµm
long ( Figs. 2A, B, D , 6A ).................
H. pivari
n. sp.
- Shield length and width about equal, or length much longer than width.......................................... 7

7. Shield tapering, up to 3 times longer than wide ( Fig. 12A ); females 2,180 â€“2,370 Î¼m long................
H. tonkinensis
- Shield width and length similar, rounded or trapezoidal in shape................................................ 8

8. Shield rounded or ovoid; lateral spines less than 20 Âµm long ( Fig. 11A ); female 1,105 â€“1,440 Î¼m long..........
H. baudini

- Shield trapezoidal; lateral spines 28â€“30 Î¼m long ( Fig. 11L ); female 1,905 â€“2,575 Î¼m long....................
H. taybaci
9. Cervical collar overlapping proximal base of anterior lateral spines............................................ 10
- Lateral cervical spines not overlapping anterior lateral spines................................................. 12

10. Eight longitudinal ridges extending from base of posterior lateral spines to vulva ( Fig. 11B ); female 2,160 â€“2,600 Î¼m long..............................................................................................
H. costata

11. Anterior and posterior lateral spine pairs fused, 26â€“33 Î¼m long; shield a semicircle, about twice as wide as long ( Fig. 11I ); females 2,700 â€“3,024 Î¼m long.................................................................
H. orthopori

- Anterior lateral spines widely separated, 50 Î¼m long; posterior lateral spines 55 Î¼m long, bases closer but not touching ( Fig. 11K ); females 2,010 â€“2,360 Î¼m long...........................................................
H. sutherlandi

13 Length of cervical spines along lappet edges irregular, some spines forked; anterior and posterior lateral spines with fused bases ( Fig. 12B ); females 1,700 â€“2,800 Î¼m long........................................................
H. tuxtlensis
- Cervical spines along lappet edges about the same size...................................................... 14

14. Shield forming a W-shape, length and width equal ( Fig. 11H ).............................................
H. juli

- Shield entire, not bilobed, well anterior to base of anterior lateral spines ( Fig. 11C ).....................
H. dimorphum

15. Wing-like lateral alae present; each pseudolabial plate with three conspicuous spines; cuticular collar with more than 100 spines; shield tapering, ( Figs. 12D ); female length 2,400 â€“2,960 Î¼m.................................
H. xaniophora

16. Anterior lateral spines widely separated; shield of typical size ( Fig. 11J ); females 1,970 â€“2,630 Î¼m long..
H. ortonwilliamsi

- Anterior lateral spines fused basally; shield trapezoidal, small ( Fig. 11F ); females 1,764 â€“1,962 Î¼m long.......
H. insularis
